article.title: Retrieving Neptune's aerosol properties from Keck OSIRIS observations. I. Dark regions

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the color bar in Figure 1 represent?
choices: Altitude of cloud features
Temperature of atmospheric layers
Average reflectance (I/F)
Methane abundance

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main absorber of light at wavelengths longer than 2.1 µm in Neptune\'s atmosphere, according to this figure?
choices: H2-H2 collision-induced absorption (CIA)
CH4 absorption
Aerosols
A combination of all absorbers

multiple_choice_question.text: How do the normalized contribution functions change with viewing geometry?
choices: They become more sensitive to deeper atmospheric layers at higher emission angles.
They become more sensitive to higher atmospheric layers at higher emission angles.
The sensitivity to different atmospheric layers remains the same at all emission angles.
The contribution functions are not affected by viewing geometry.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the orange dot-dashed line represent in the center panel of Figure 4?
choices: The initial CH4 profile used in the analysis
The CH4 profile selected after testing various profiles (SN CH4gridE)
A CH4 profile with 100% relative humidity near the tropopause
A CH4 profile with a depletion depth of 4.0 bar

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the model "tolerance" (σt) represent in Equation 1?
choices: Uncertainties in the data noise level
Uncertainties in the photometric calibration
Unknown uncertainties, including deficiencies in the model
The total uncertainty in the model
